articles.headline: E.U. Takes Aim at Big Tech’s Power With Landmark Digital Act
articles.snippet: The Digital Markets Act is the most sweeping legislation to regulate tech since a European privacy law was passed in 2018.
articles.abstract: The Digital Markets Act is the most sweeping legislation to regulate tech since a European privacy law was passed in 2018.
articles.lead_paragraph: GÖTTINGEN, Germany — The European Union agreed on Thursday to one of the world’s most far-reaching laws to address the power of the biggest tech companies, potentially reshaping app stores, online advertising, e-commerce, messaging services and other everyday digital tools.

articles.headline: Biden and his allies vow to take a tougher stance; Ukraine counteroffensive enters its second week
articles.snippet: In a day of summit meetings, President Biden and his counterparts faced the prospect of Russia using weapons of mass destruction. Mr. Biden said the United States would admit 100,000 Ukrainian refugees.
articles.abstract: In a day of summit meetings, President Biden and his counterparts faced the prospect of Russia using weapons of mass destruction. Mr. Biden said the United States would admit 100,000 Ukrainian refugees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live news updates on the Russia-Ukraine war.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

articles.headline: Ukraine Tries to Seize Momentum With Claims of Counteroffensive
articles.snippet: The picture on the ground is muddy and it’s unclear how much territory Ukraine has gained back. But its announcement of a counteroffensive has enhanced the notion that it is taking the fight to the enemy.
articles.abstract: The picture on the ground is muddy and it’s unclear how much territory Ukraine has gained back. But its announcement of a counteroffensive has enhanced the notion that it is taking the fight to the enemy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live news updates on the Russia-Ukraine war.

articles.headline: Ginni Thomas Pressed Trump’s Chief of Staff to Overturn 2020 Vote, Texts Show
articles.snippet: Messages between Justice Clarence Thomas’s wife and Mark Meadows are the first evidence that she directly advised the White House to reverse the election results.
articles.abstract: Messages between Justice Clarence Thomas’s wife and Mark Meadows are the first evidence that she directly advised the White House to reverse the election results.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the weeks between the 2020 presidential election and the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, Virginia Thomas, the wife of Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas, sent a barrage of text messages imploring President Donald J. Trump’s chief of staff to take steps to overturn the vote, according to a person with knowledge of the texts.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim, Luke Broadwater and Jo Becker

articles.headline: The Respectful Supreme Court Hearing That Wasn’t
articles.snippet: Republicans’ hostile interrogation of Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson and relentless re-litigating of past Supreme Court feuds marred a historic moment.
articles.abstract: Republicans’ hostile interrogation of Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson and relentless re-litigating of past Supreme Court feuds marred a historic moment.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Republican manhandling of Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson this week was convincing evidence that the Senate’s Supreme Court confirmation process is irredeemably broken.

articles.headline: One of Europe’s Largest Retailers, Still in Russia, Angers Its Ukraine Workers
articles.snippet: The destruction of a Leroy Merlin store in Kyiv by a Russian missile underscores the conflicting interests facing companies that continue to do business in Russia.
articles.abstract: The destruction of a Leroy Merlin store in Kyiv by a Russian missile underscores the conflicting interests facing companies that continue to do business in Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Shortly after a Russian rocket obliterated one of the largest shopping malls in Kyiv on Monday, Ukrainian employees of Leroy Merlin, a home improvement store that was destroyed in the blast, commandeered the company’s Ukraine Instagram page.

articles.headline: Why the U.S. Can’t Quickly Wean Europe From Russian Gas
articles.snippet: The Biden administration’s plan to send more natural gas to Europe will be hampered by the lack of export and import terminals.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration’s plan to send more natural gas to Europe will be hampered by the lack of export and import terminals.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — President Biden announced Friday that the United States would send more natural gas to Europe to help it break its dependence on Russian energy. But that plan will largely be symbolic, at least in the short run, because the United States doesn’t have enough capacity to export more gas and Europe doesn’t have the capacity to import significantly more.

articles.headline: She Was a Candidate to Lead Levi’s. Then She Started Tweeting.
articles.snippet: Jennifer Sey left Levi’s after her advocacy against school closures and mask mandates for children gained attention. She says it’s a matter of free speech. The company disagrees.
articles.abstract: Jennifer Sey left Levi’s after her advocacy against school closures and mask mandates for children gained attention. She says it’s a matter of free speech. The company disagrees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before 2020, Jennifer Sey, a top executive at Levi Strauss & Company and a leading candidate to be the company’s next leader, barely used social media. Two years later, Ms. Sey was out of a job, in part, in her telling, because of her activity on Twitter.

articles.headline: How the 2022 Primaries Are Testing Trump’s Role as the G.O.P. ‘Kingpin’
articles.snippet: Two of Donald Trump’s most prominent Senate endorsements have already backfired. Now the month of May looms large to measure his pull on the party.
articles.abstract: Two of Donald Trump’s most prominent Senate endorsements have already backfired. Now the month of May looms large to measure his pull on the party.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has sought to establish himself as the Republican Party’s undisputed kingmaker in the 2022 midterms, issuing more than 120 endorsements to elevate allies, punish those who have crossed him and turn his baseless claim that the 2020 election was stolen into a litmus test for the party.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Israel to Host 3 Arab Foreign Ministers in Historic Meeting
articles.snippet: The gathering of top diplomats from Israel, the U.A.E., Bahrain and Morocco, as well as Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, is a sign of how quickly Middle Eastern alliances are shifting.
articles.abstract: The gathering of top diplomats from Israel, the U.A.E., Bahrain and Morocco, as well as Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, is a sign of how quickly Middle Eastern alliances are shifting.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel will host a historic summit this weekend with the top diplomats from the United States, the United Arab Emirates, Morocco and Bahrain, a sign of how quickly the realignment of Middle Eastern powers is accelerating as Israelis and some Arab governments find common cause not only over Iran but in navigating the new global realities created by the Ukraine war.

articles.headline: Bad Tidings From the Bond Market
articles.snippet: The usually sedate bond market has been unsettled by worries about inflation, the Federal Reserve’s interest rate increases and even the possibility of a recession.
articles.abstract: The usually sedate bond market has been unsettled by worries about inflation, the Federal Reserve’s interest rate increases and even the possibility of a recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stock market usually gets the headlines while its bigger cousin, the bond market, customarily plays a more sedate role, quietly generating steady returns with little fanfare.

articles.headline: The Fed Bets on a ‘Soft Landing,’ but Recession Risk Looms
articles.snippet: Central bankers have been clear that they will do what it takes to control inflation. They are betting on a soft landing, but a bumpy one is possible.
articles.abstract: Central bankers have been clear that they will do what it takes to control inflation. They are betting on a soft landing, but a bumpy one is possible.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, emphasized this week that the central bank he leads could succeed in its quest to tame rapid inflation without causing unemployment to rise or setting off a recession. But he also acknowledged that such a benign outcome was not certain.
